Argument for “Mapping Planets and Collecting Precious Stones”

I. Restating Our Thesis  
  Our mission is a geological survey—prospecting and mapping worlds for valuable minerals—not live‐capture of aliens.

II. Positive Evidence for Mineral Prospecting  
  1. Captain’s Expertise and Concerns  
    – <invalid_quote>“In civilian life, I was a lapidary…and I never got…to tap a million‐dollar gem.”</invalid_quote>  
       • Selection criterion: a lapidary’s skill is only useful prospecting for gems.  
    – “One mistake was too many…I might have ruined an exploration and destroyed a man, not a stone.”  
       • Captain equates human loss to loss of a gem and “exploration.” Stone is the primary asset.  
  2. Use of Survey Equipment and Cables  
    – <invalid_quote>“We have three miles of cable…Parties are strung out…cable…fast to the hull.”</invalid_quote>  
       • Mineral surveying uses limited loops to chart terrain and locate deposits, returning repeatedly to base.  
    – “I took a sighting…thin thread of violet…There was something broken and twisted at the bottom.”  
       • Language of prospectors “tracing veins” with radar. No mention of transport of biomass.  
  3. Cannibalization and Mobility Priority  
    – <quote>sets. We can take apart the tractors and put our ship back together again after we complete the survey." "You</quote>  
       • Sacrificing tractors would be absurd if goal were capturing/hauling heavy biological specimens. They value base ship to continue “survey.”  
    – Final action: “tractors torn down…spaceship where they belong.”  
       • They rebuild to resume exploring new sectors.  
  4. Indirect, Cautious Attitude Toward Aliens  
    – “Let’s take…a specimen!” is preceded by warning “they may be dangerous,” and is a drunken, naïve action.  
    – <quote> We aren't allowed to dissect creatures that  far up the intelligence scale."</quote>  
       • Interstellar regulations bar aggressive capture.  
    – Post‐rescue: “The aliens were trying to help…they want Earthmen to colonize the planet.”  
       • Colonization is aliens’ goal, not ours. We accept “hospitality” to facilitate further survey.  

III. Refuting “Capturing Aliens” Arguments  
  1. “Specimen” Attempt Is Incidental and Foolish  
    – Only one drunken side‐excursion beyond safety; they immediately haul Quade back and return to base. No systematic capture devices, specimen tanks, anesthesia, or quarantine.  
  2. Translator and Indoctrination Serve Sensor Calibration  
    – Captain: <invalid_quote>“Translator…recognize all confused data…starting indoctrination courses.”</invalid_quote>  
       • Purpose: overcome “transphasia” for accurate sensory data in mapping.  
    – Music and wine experiments further sensory calibration. No logical link to biological specimen collection.  
  3. Lack of Geological Sampling Tools Is Not Evidence  
    – Cartographer unit implies mapping, not range finding for traps. Prospectors use sensors, not manual “sampling.” Weight precludes return on foot; sampling would wait for tractor transport once field is mapped.  
  4. Mission Prioritizes Ship Integrity Over Extended Forays  
    – They fear “electrogravitational jamming” and stay near cable; a bio‐survey would crave extended ranges to trap animals.  

IV. Why “Mapping and Gem‐Collecting” Is the Only Viable Mission  
  1. Resource Constraints  
    – Limited cable length, fuel, suit endurance, and time—geological surveying requires base proximity; biocapture missions would deploy heavy equipment and transport.  
  2. Captain’s Demotion of Quade Reflects Need for Survey Expertise  
    – Quade’s “cocksure” transphasia defenses hamper methodical approach; captain’s careful procedures align with scientific data gathering, not reckless hunts.  
  3. Final Outcome Focuses on Future Surveys  
    – “I must inform you…demoting…space isn’t as dangerous.” They plan indoctrination for future “surveys.” No mention of live specimens aboard or shipping.  

V. Conclusion  
  All logistical choices—proximity cables, cargo tractors, sensory‐calibration experiments, ethical restraint toward sapient life—point to methodical mapping and mineral prospecting. The single “specimen” fling is a desperate, foolish moment, not the mission’s intent. “Capturing aliens” is incidental at best, whereas gem collection and planetary surveying are explicitly supported by Captain Gavin’s expertise, decisions, and resources.
